reflections.title: Reflecting
reflections.description: A close friend sent me a photo from a holiday in Portugal in which she is reading whilst a young child plays. Instantly I loved the photo for the reflection through the window and the serenity on a hot afternoon in the sun. Not so simple to paint, though!

reflections.title: Reflections, Casa de Serralves, Porto
reflections.description: This painting is from a shot I took at the Museum of Modern Art and Architecture at the Casa de Serralves in Porto. The light and reflection were overwhelmingly beautiful. I then work on the painting during the first lockdown in March 2020 and it was a great escape

reflections.title: Peeping from the Tate Modern
reflections.description: The scene is on the top floor. I just love the arrangement of brick, reflecting glass, and the block of flats opposite. You may recall the famous court case? Hence the title.

reflections.title: Hiroshima Museum of Art, Naka-ku
reflections.description: Reflection is a theme on which I have been working for the last two years. ‘Inside-out’ or ‘jeu de lumière’ obliges the eye to work out what’s going on and this injects interest.

reflections.title: Orange Window in Albi, Aveyron
reflections.description: Albi is two hours from my home in France and is a beautiful and interesting town, home to Toulouse Lautrec’s paintings. This painting is part of a series on reflections that aims to challenge the viewer to work out what is real and what is a reflection. This painting is also the model for a larger work.

reflections.title: Flooded field, Avebury
reflections.description: Before starting work, I walk most days down this lane in Avebury where the river floods most winters. I painted this picture attracted by the reflection of the trees on the water.

reflections.title: Reflections on the lake
reflections.description: From time to time I like to paint a landscape in a traditional manner and here is an example.

reflections.title: The River Lot at Cahors
reflections.description: The current on the river Lot is powerful and without mercy, taking tree trunks with it. I loved the clarity of the water by the weir with the undisturbed shadow of the trees contrasting with the movement of the river itself.

isolations.title: Abandoned, Dungeness, Kent
isolations.description: I took a photo of this abandoned building a long time ago. The area is very atmospheric and I felt that this structure had a life to tell. It was only after reading Cal Flyn’s fascinating book ‘Islands of Abandonment’ that I decided to create the painting.

isolations.title: The Barn at Windmill Hill, Avebury
isolations.description: This painting is part of a series on abandoned buildings. I regularly walk by this barn, which was once an elegant workplace but now has only a broken chair and is open to the elements sweeping across a bare Wiltshire landscape.

isolations.title: It’s the end not the journey that matters
isolations.description: This is the train station at Porto in Portugal, fascinating architecturally and impressive in size. The lady on the bench hardly moved during the hour and a half we spent waiting for our train. Perhaps she had given up hope that she would ever reach her destination.

isolations.title: Silbury Hill, Avebury
isolations.description: A small drawing of Silbury Hill, a mound constructed between 2400 and 2300 BCE and a wonder of Wiltshire. I am very fortunate to live a mile away from this extraordinary site of natural beauty.

isolations.title: Parc Josaphat, Brussels
isolations.description: We had some very bitterly cold and snowy winters during a decade spent in Brussels and this drawing shows the park looking very different from its usual verdant self. The contrast between the heavy grey sky with the dark trees and the white snow with the workman’s orange overall resembles a Japanese scene.

isolations.title: Le four à pain at Pech Rasquet, France
isolations.description: The Pissaro exhibition at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford inspired me to paint this traditional bread oven. Pissaro exerted a powerful influence not only on his own time but also today. A great painter.

isolations.title: To the lighthouse, Brittany
isolations.description: An atmospheric sea on a dull grey day with the view out to sea looking flat, just like a theatre set, and with a hint of mystery, as though the curtain has gone up on a stage whilst the audience waits for the play to start.

isolations.title: Barbara Hepworth’s work studio, St Ives
isolations.description: When I visited, I felt the great sculptor Barbara Hepworth’s presence in her remarkable studio.

isolations.title: Porto Train Station, Portugal
isolations.description: Whilst waiting for a train, my imagination went wild in this impressive station. my painting contrasts the rectilinear architecture with free-floating colours on the track. In fact the station was exemplary in its cleanliness!

isolations.title: Dew Pond, Ridgeway, Avebury
isolations.materials: acrylic and chinese ink on paper
isolations.description: This painting is very dear to me. I wanted to show beauty on a cold misty morning with a feeling of closeness and serenity.

isolations.title: Winter Sunset
isolations.materials: water colour and chinese ink on paper
isolations.description: A limited edition of signed Giclée prints of this painting is available.

isolations.title: Dom Luis Bridge, Porto, Portugal
isolations.description: This bridge, perched in the sky and with minimal movement across it, contrasts with the unseen but busy city below.

perceptions.title: London Mews
perceptions.description: This painting was the preparatory model of a much larger work for a commission for clients in Central London. It represents the street of their pied à terre and the commission covers a wall on the stairwell, beautifully lit by a huge skylight.

perceptions.title: A view from the plain
perceptions.description: If you drive from Aosta towards the mountains, the contrast between the very flat plain and the high chain of mountains in front of you is surreal; hence this painting. I chose this blue to mark the surreal effect of the landscape and the sensation of surprise from seeing it.

perceptions.title: Sunday washing in Venice
perceptions.description: This painting shows how it is possible to work on perpective and depth using a technique using squares, which has evolved from the screen ‘Square’ (see photo).

perceptions.title: Veranda in St Germain en Laye
perceptions.description: There are wonderful old houses in St Germain and this terrace is perched on the first floor. My painting has different layers to intrigue the eye.

perceptions.title: Flowers and Squares
perceptions.materials: acrylic, pastel and ink on paper
perceptions.description: The application of squares in this painting adds perspective and depth but it hopes also to intrigue the viewer as to what is what in the picture.

perceptions.title: Street View, Bristol
perceptions.description: This painting represents protective building boards that had been coloured. In itself, this structure was a work of art especially with the shadow of the the tree and the child passing by.

perceptions.title: La danse des hirondelles
perceptions.description: This painting is a trompe d’oeil. What do you see? Are you sure? The composition seems straight-forward and simple but the more you look, the more it reveals. A certain amount of mathematical calculation was required, which is not my forte …
